title: Detection horizon for the neutrino burst from the stellar helium flash
comment: 14 pages, 7 figures, 1 table, 2 appendices
summary: Low-mass stars ($M\lesssim 2\,M_\odot$) ignite helium under degenerate conditions, eventually causing a nuclear run-away -- the helium flash. The alpha-capture process on $^{14}$N produces a large amount of $^{18}$F, whose subsequent decay spawns an intense $ν_e$ burst (with average energy of $0.38$ MeV) lasting about a day. We show that, in addition, a strong $1.7$ MeV neutrino line is generated by electron capture on $^{18}$F. Detection is hindered by large backgrounds in state-of-the-art neutrino observatories, such as JUNO. In next-generation facilities, such as the Jinping neutrino experiment, the horizon for a detection with a local significance of $3 σ$ would be extended to almost $3$ pc. Although helium flashes occur a few times per year in our Galaxy, there are no stellar candidates approaching the tip of the red giant branch within $10$ pc. Hence, to date, asteroseismology remains the most promising tool for probing the most energetic thermonuclear event in the life of a low-mass star.

AI.tldr: Low-mass stars produce intense neutrino bursts during helium flashes, including a distinctive 1.7 MeV line from electron capture on ¹⁸F, but detection is challenging due to backgrounds and lack of nearby candidates.
AI.motivation: To investigate neutrino emission from helium flashes in low-mass stars and assess detectability in current and future neutrino observatories.
AI.method: Analyze nuclear processes during helium flashes, particularly alpha-capture on ¹⁴N producing ¹⁸F, and calculate neutrino emission including the 1.7 MeV line from electron capture on ¹⁸F. Evaluate detection prospects using background models for observatories like JUNO and Jinping.
AI.result: Helium flashes generate intense ν_e bursts (average 0.38 MeV) lasting ~1 day plus a strong 1.7 MeV neutrino line. Detection is hindered by backgrounds; Jinping could achieve 3σ detection out to ~3 pc. No suitable stellar candidates exist within 10 pc, making direct detection currently infeasible.
AI.conclusion: While helium flashes produce distinctive neutrino signals, asteroseismology remains the most promising tool for studying these events due to detection challenges and lack of nearby stellar candidates.

title: The eruptive young star IRAS 21204+4913
comment: 16 pages, 12 figures. Submitted to Astronomy Letters
summary: The results of photometric, polarimetric, and spectroscopic observations are presented for the young star IRAS 21204+4913, whose visible brightness has increased by $\approx 5^{\rm m}$ since October 2025. The star's absorption spectrum in the $0.36 - 0.75 μ$m range resembles those of A - F giants and supergiants, but it also exhibits molecular TiO bands. The brightening was accompanied by a significant increase in the degree of polarization of the stellar radiation (to $\approx 16 \%$ in the I-band), likely due to scattering by dust in an expanding circumstellar shell. The P Cygni profile of the H$α$ line implies a dusty wind velocity of $\approx 300$ km/s. We believe that the outburst of IRAS 21204+4913 is caused by an increase in the accretion rate of protoplanetary disk's matter onto the young star with a mass of $\lesssim 0.5$ M$_\odot$ to $\gtrsim 3\times 10^{-5}$ M$_\odot$ yr$^{-1}$. Furthermore, IRAS 21204+4913 displays several unusual features: the dependence of the width and radial velocity of absorption lines on the excitation potential, emission in the TiO molecular bands, and a comparably bright outburst that occured in 1948. Several T Tauri stars and a group of Herbig-Haro objects are found in the vicinity of the star.

AI.tldr: IRAS 21204+4913 experienced a ~5 magnitude brightening in October 2025, accompanied by increased polarization (~16% in I-band) and spectroscopic changes indicating a dusty wind (~300 km/s), likely due to enhanced accretion onto a young low-mass star.
AI.motivation: To characterize the unusual outburst of the young star IRAS 21204+4913, which brightened by ~5 magnitudes, and understand the physical mechanisms behind this event through multi-wavelength observations.
AI.method: Multi-technique observational approach including photometric monitoring, polarimetric measurements, and spectroscopic analysis across 0.36-0.75 μm range to study brightness changes, polarization properties, and spectral features.
AI.result: The star shows A-F giant/supergiant-like absorption spectra with TiO bands, ~16% polarization increase in I-band, P Cygni Hα profile indicating ~300 km/s dusty wind, and evidence of enhanced accretion rate to ≥3×10⁻⁵ M⊙/yr onto a ≤0.5 M⊙ young star.
AI.conclusion: The outburst is caused by increased accretion from the protoplanetary disk, with unusual features including excitation-dependent line properties, TiO emission, historical 1948 outburst, and association with T Tauri stars and Herbig-Haro objects in the region.

title: New Insights from Revisiting the Rotation Period of the Strongly Magnetic O Star, NGC 1624-2
comment: 18 pages, 6 figures, 3 tables
summary: NGC 1624-2 hosts the strongest surface magnetic field found on an O star thus far. When applied across several epochs of observations, the star's currently accepted rotation period (157.99 d) does not coherently characterize the variations of spectral lines of magnetospheric origin. We analyze Lomb-Scargle periodograms produced with new and archival, multi-instrument spectroscopic time series of Balmer H and He spectral lines. We find that 153.17 $\pm$ 0.42 d and 306.56 $\pm$ 1.19 d are both equally suitable periods at phasing the spectral and magnetic time series data in a manner consistent with the Oblique Rotator Model. The 306.56 d period implies a magnetic geometry for NGC 1624-2 that is quite different from the previously accepted one, for which both magnetic poles should be observed during a full rotational cycle. If this is the case, the star's magnetic South pole has yet to be observed, and additional spectropolarimetric observations should be acquired in order to confirm whether or not the south pole is in fact observable.

AI.tldr: The paper analyzes the rotation period of magnetized O star NGC 1624-2, finding two equally suitable periods (153.17d and 306.56d) that better characterize spectral variations than the previously accepted 157.99d period.
AI.motivation: The currently accepted rotation period (157.99 days) for NGC 1624-2 does not coherently characterize variations in spectral lines of magnetospheric origin across multiple epochs, requiring re-examination of the star's rotational properties.
AI.method: Analyzed Lomb-Scargle periodograms using new and archival multi-instrument spectroscopic time series of Balmer H and He spectral lines to identify alternative rotation periods that better phase the spectral and magnetic time series data.
AI.result: Found two equally suitable periods: 153.17 ± 0.42 days and 306.56 ± 1.19 days, both of which better characterize the spectral variations. The longer period suggests a different magnetic geometry where only one magnetic pole is observed per cycle.
AI.conclusion: The 306.56-day period implies a magnetic geometry where both magnetic poles should be observable during a full rotational cycle, suggesting the magnetic South pole has yet to be observed and requiring additional spectropolarimetric observations for confirmation.

title: On the dynamics, thermodynamics and fine structure of virtual erupting filaments
comment: 14 pages, 14 figures, accepted for publication in A&A
summary: It is not fully understood why some solar filaments erupt while others do not. Those that do typically undergo a slow rise followed by an acceleration phase, though this transition requires further investigation. Erupting prominences have been observed to heat up during the acceleration phase, but the origin of this heating remains unclear. Moreover, some coronal mass ejections possess additional fine structure in white-light observations beyond the classical three-part morphology. We aim to elaborate on the dynamics of erupting prominences, investigate the heating during the acceleration phase, and correlate our findings with observations. We employ the open-source MPI-AMRVAC code to solve the 2.5D MHD equations on a coronal domain extending to 300 Mm, using adaptive mesh refinement to attain high resolution. Controlled combinations of footpoint shearing and converging motions applied to an initial magnetic arcade produce erupting flux ropes with self-consistent prominence and coronal rain formation due to thermal instability. We find both non-erupting and erupting cases related to the system energization. Comparison with observations from the AIA Filament Eruption Catalog shows that the slow-rise and impulsive phases are modulated by magnetic reconnection. The transition to acceleration corresponds to an increase in the inflow Alfvén Mach number. Thermal conduction and compressional heating can lead to prominence evaporation. We obtain nested circular fine structure in EUV images of the ejected flux ropes, partly resulting from plasmoid interactions. We conclude that internal heating processes and magnetic reconnection play key roles in the early evolution of CMEs.

AI.tldr: 2.5D MHD simulations reveal that magnetic reconnection drives filament eruption phases, with heating during acceleration caused by thermal conduction and compressional heating, producing EUV fine structure.
AI.motivation: To understand why some solar filaments erupt while others don't, investigate the heating during the acceleration phase, and explain additional fine structure in coronal mass ejections beyond the classical three-part morphology.
AI.method: Used open-source MPI-AMRVAC code to solve 2.5D MHD equations on a coronal domain extending to 300 Mm with adaptive mesh refinement. Applied controlled combinations of footpoint shearing and converging motions to initial magnetic arcades to produce erupting flux ropes with self-consistent prominence and coronal rain formation via thermal instability.
AI.result: Both non-erupting and erupting cases related to system energization. Slow-rise and impulsive phases modulated by magnetic reconnection. Transition to acceleration corresponds to increase in inflow Alfvén Mach number. Thermal conduction and compressional heating cause prominence evaporation. Nested circular fine structure in EUV images of ejected flux ropes results partly from plasmoid interactions.
AI.conclusion: Internal heating processes and magnetic reconnection play key roles in the early evolution of coronal mass ejections, explaining eruption dynamics, heating during acceleration, and fine structure formation.

title: Intracluster globular clusters as tracers of the mass assembly of the Hydra I galaxy cluster
comment: Accepted for publication in A&A. 18 pages, 20 figures
summary: In galaxy clusters, hierarchical assembly predicts the formation of stellar substructures and intracluster light (ICL), a diffuse stellar component tracing the global cluster potential. Because these features are extremely faint, alternative tracers such as globular clusters (GCs) provide a powerful tool to study cluster assembly. We use deep VLT/FORS $V$- and $I$-band imaging to investigate the GC population in the nearby Hydra I galaxy cluster ($\sim 45.7$ Mpc). GC candidates were selected from the $VI$ colour-magnitude diagram and divided into blue and red subpopulations. We find a clear spatial dichotomy: red GCs are concentrated around the massive central galaxies NGC 3311 and NGC 3309, while blue GCs are more extended and offset from the centre, coinciding with a secondary peak of X-ray-emitting gas. In the central regions, GC spatial distributions further depend on stellar population properties: young metal-rich GCs are more extended and may be linked to ram-pressure stripping, whereas old metal-poor GCs are more centrally concentrated, possibly originating from disrupted dwarf galaxies. Comparing the GC number density profiles to the surface brightness profile of NGC 3311, we find that the red GCs closely follow the galaxy light, while the blue population significantly deviates from it and traces the global gravitational potential of the cluster. This is also reflected in the specific frequency of blue GCs, which is approximately $\sim 5\times$ higher in the ICL-dominated outskirts than in the inner regions dominated by red GCs. Finally, we present a novel method to constrain the evolution of the galaxy luminosity function of the cluster using GC specific frequencies and colour distributions, yielding a past faint-end slope of $α=-1.81^{+0.16}_{-0.16}$ compared to $α=-1.41^{+0.08}_{-0.05}$ today, consistent with high-redshift observations and cosmological simulations.

AI.tldr: Study of globular cluster populations in Hydra I cluster reveals spatial dichotomy: red GCs trace central galaxies while blue GCs trace cluster potential and ICL, providing constraints on cluster assembly history.
AI.motivation: To understand galaxy cluster assembly through faint stellar features like intracluster light (ICL) using globular clusters as alternative tracers, particularly in the nearby Hydra I cluster.
AI.method: Deep VLT/FORS V- and I-band imaging to select GC candidates via VI color-magnitude diagram, divided into blue/red subpopulations; spatial distribution analysis; comparison with galaxy light and X-ray gas; novel method using GC specific frequencies and colors to constrain galaxy luminosity function evolution.
AI.result: Clear spatial dichotomy: red GCs concentrated around central galaxies NGC 3311/3309; blue GCs extended and offset, coinciding with X-ray gas peak. Red GCs follow galaxy light; blue GCs trace cluster potential. Blue GC specific frequency ~5× higher in ICL-dominated outskirts. Constrained past faint-end slope of galaxy luminosity function: α=-1.81 vs. α=-1.41 today.
AI.conclusion: GC populations provide powerful tracers of cluster assembly: red GCs trace central galaxy formation, blue GCs trace hierarchical assembly and ICL formation. Spatial and population differences reveal different formation mechanisms, with novel method successfully recovering cluster assembly history consistent with cosmological simulations.

title: Barium Stars Across the Milky Way: Probing Their Origins via the GALAH Survey
comment: 23 pages, 12 figures, 5 tables, accepted to ApJ
summary: Barium stars are unusually enriched in barium ([Ba/Fe] >= 1.0 dex) and not predicted by current Galactic chemical evolution models. Previous observations of barium stars have found evidence that they form through mass transfer from a companion asymptotic giant branch (AGB) star or through radiative levitation. The chemical abundance and kinematic information of barium stars may help constrain AGB stellar nucleosynthesis, binary star evolution, and internal evolutionary processes that affect surface abundances. Using ~450,000 stars from the GALactic Archaeology with Hermes (GALAH) survey, we identify nearly 3000 new barium-rich stars and separate them into hot (Teff > 6000 K) and cool (Teff < 6000 K) populations. Cross-matching with Gaia DR3, we find that 47.7% of our barium stars within 1 kpc have elevated re-normalized unit weight error (RUWE >= 1.4), compared to 16.3% of a comparable sample of the GALAH field, suggesting multiplicity plays an important role in the formation of both populations of barium stars. A subset of hot barium stars exhibit low RUWE (RUWE < 1.2) and [alpha/Fe] < -0.2, supporting radiative levitation as an origin as well. We determine Galactic memberships using both kinematics and chemistry and find that barium stars exist in the thin disk, thick disk, and halo though they are slightly more prevalent at lower metallicities. Overall, we show evidence for barium stars produced by mass transfer and for those produced by radiative levitation, with both formation mechanisms occurring ubiquitously across the Galaxy.

AI.tldr: Study identifies ~3000 new barium-rich stars from GALAH survey, finding evidence for both binary mass transfer and radiative levitation formation mechanisms across the Galaxy.
AI.motivation: Barium stars are chemically peculiar (Ba-enriched) and not predicted by standard Galactic chemical evolution models. Their formation mechanisms (binary mass transfer vs. radiative levitation) and Galactic distribution need clarification to constrain AGB nucleosynthesis, binary evolution, and internal stellar processes.
AI.method: Used ~450,000 stars from GALAH survey to identify barium-rich stars ([Ba/Fe] ≥ 1.0 dex). Separated into hot (Teff > 6000 K) and cool (Teff < 6000 K) populations. Cross-matched with Gaia DR3 to analyze multiplicity via RUWE (re-normalized unit weight error). Determined Galactic memberships using kinematics and chemistry.
AI.result: Identified ~3000 new barium-rich stars. Found 47.7% of barium stars within 1 kpc have elevated RUWE (≥1.4) vs. 16.3% in field stars, indicating high binary fraction. Hot barium stars with low RUWE (<1.2) and low [α/Fe] (<-0.2) support radiative levitation origin. Barium stars exist in thin disk, thick disk, and halo, slightly more prevalent at lower metallicities.
AI.conclusion: Both mass transfer from AGB companions and radiative levitation contribute to barium star formation, with both mechanisms occurring ubiquitously across the Galaxy. Multiplicity plays important role in formation of both hot and cool barium star populations.

title: Coronal Non-Thermal and Doppler Plasma Flows Driven by Photospheric Flux in 28 Active Regions
comment: Accepted for publication in PASJ
summary: Magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) waves and/or the braiding of magnetic field lines are largely thought to be responsible for heating the solar corona, both being mechanisms which are driven by the Sun's photospheric magnetic field. Recent modelling work leads us to expect that such heating mechanisms would be seen in the excess broadening (non-thermal velocity) of coronal spectral emission lines and that larger magnitudes of photospheric magnetic flux would generate more heating, but a direct connection between magnetic flux and spectral line broadening has been difficult to establish. We combine measurements of the photospheric magnetic field from SDO/HMI and non-thermal velocity in log T~6.2 coronal plasma from Hinode/EIS for 28 active regions and find a moderate correlation between the two exists in quiescent active regions, consistent with the photospheric field injecting upward Poynting flux into the solar corona and causing coronal heating. We find that no strong correlation with coronal composition makes it difficult to distinguish between MHD wave heating and magnetic field braiding heating using these diagnostics with current instrumentation.

AI.tldr: Study finds moderate correlation between photospheric magnetic flux and coronal spectral line broadening in quiescent active regions, supporting photospheric field injecting Poynting flux for coronal heating.
AI.motivation: To establish a direct connection between photospheric magnetic flux and coronal spectral line broadening (non-thermal velocity) as evidence for coronal heating mechanisms driven by photospheric magnetic field.
AI.method: Combined measurements of photospheric magnetic field from SDO/HMI and non-thermal velocity in log T~6.2 coronal plasma from Hinode/EIS for 28 active regions.
AI.result: Found moderate correlation between photospheric magnetic flux and spectral line broadening in quiescent active regions, consistent with photospheric field injecting upward Poynting flux into corona.
AI.conclusion: Results support photospheric magnetic field as driver of coronal heating, but current instrumentation cannot distinguish between MHD wave heating and magnetic field braiding heating mechanisms.

title: The diverse nature of spiral arms in the Auriga Superstars cosmological hydrodynamic simulations
comment: submitted to MNRAS
summary: The dynamical nature and formation mechanism(s) of galactic spiral arms remain long-standing problems in astrophysics. Most theoretical work is based on analytic calculations or idealised simulations, which has yielded several theories of spiral structure. The radial profile of the spiral arm rotation speed - the pattern speed - is a key observable prediction of these theories. However, observations that infer spiral pattern speeds reveal a mixed picture with no clear consensus. Here, we expand on theoretical efforts by examining the pattern speed profiles in the Auriga Superstars set of high-resolution cosmological magnetohydrodynamic simulatons of Milky Way-mass spiral disc galaxies. These simulations combine galaxy formation in a cosmological environment with the high dynamical fidelity afforded by an $\sim 800$ $\rm M_{\odot}$ star particle resolution, giving $\sim 100$ million star particles in the disc. We show that several different spiral arm theories are realised among our simulations, including large-scale kinematic density waves, manifold spirals, dynamic (co-rotating) spirals, and overlapping modes. In particular, we demonstrate that a strong tidal interaction leads to clear kinematic density waves, and that manifold spirals are present in a strongly-barred galaxy. Interestingly, we find that the same galaxy may show qualitative evolution of their spiral pattern speed profiles, indicating that the nature of spiral arms can evolve on potentially sub-Gigayear timescales. Our results demonstrate that in the absence of a strong external encounter or a strong bar, galactic spiral structure is highly transitional and complex with no clear long-lived underlying wave.

AI.tldr: Cosmological simulations reveal multiple spiral arm formation mechanisms coexist in Milky Way-mass galaxies, with pattern speeds evolving on sub-Gyr timescales, showing spiral structure is transitional without strong external perturbations.
AI.motivation: The dynamical nature and formation mechanisms of galactic spiral arms remain unresolved problems in astrophysics, with conflicting observational evidence about spiral pattern speeds and no clear consensus from existing theoretical work.
AI.method: Analysis of pattern speed profiles in the Auriga Superstars set of high-resolution cosmological magnetohydrodynamic simulations of Milky Way-mass spiral disc galaxies, featuring ~800 M⊙ star particle resolution and ~100 million star particles in discs.
AI.result: Multiple spiral arm theories are realized in simulations: large-scale kinematic density waves, manifold spirals, dynamic (co-rotating) spirals, and overlapping modes. Strong tidal interactions produce clear kinematic density waves, while manifold spirals appear in strongly-barred galaxies. Spiral pattern speed profiles can evolve qualitatively on sub-Gyr timescales.
AI.conclusion: Spiral structure in galaxies without strong external encounters or bars is highly transitional and complex, lacking clear long-lived underlying waves, explaining the mixed observational picture of spiral pattern speeds.

title: A homogeneous view of asymptotic giant branch carbon stars as seen by Gaia
comment: Accepted in A&A on 17 February 2026
summary:
Carbon stars on the asymptotic giant branch are major contributors to galactic dust enrichment, with gas mass-loss rates up to 1e-4 Msun/yr. We present a homogeneous spectral energy distribution analysis of the Gaia DR3 Golden Sample of carbon stars in the Milky Way and Magellanic Clouds. Our dataset includes 14,747 sources with multi-band photometry from Gaia, 2MASS, and WISE, combined with recent distance and extinction estimates. For a subsample of 2,494 Mira variables, we model multi-band light curves to derive accurate mean magnitudes.
  Stellar and circumstellar parameters are obtained by fitting observations with a large grid of synthetic spectra computed with the DUSTY radiative transfer code using COMARCS atmospheres. We derive effective temperature, optical depth, and gas mass-loss rate for each source. The distributions peak around Teff = 3150 K, with mass-loss rates spanning 1e-11 to 1e-4 Msun/yr and inner dust temperatures near 1000 K. We find a correlation between variability amplitude and mass-loss rate.
  This framework provides a statistically robust view of carbon stars across environments with different metallicities. Apparent environmental dependencies are influenced by luminosity distributions and selection effects rather than purely intrinsic metallicity differences. The combined Gaia and WISE selection limits the detection of both highly obscured and faint Magellanic Cloud sources, but the observed trends remain significant within the sampled populations.

AI.tldr: Homogeneous spectral energy distribution analysis of 14,747 carbon stars from Gaia DR3 reveals stellar parameters, mass-loss rates, and environmental dependencies across Milky Way and Magellanic Clouds.
AI.motivation: Carbon stars on the asymptotic giant branch are major dust producers with high mass-loss rates, but systematic studies across different galactic environments with varying metallicities are needed to understand their properties and evolution.
AI.method: Used Gaia DR3 Golden Sample of carbon stars with multi-band photometry from Gaia, 2MASS, and WISE. Fitted observations with synthetic spectra from DUSTY radiative transfer code using COMARCS atmospheres. For 2,494 Mira variables, modeled multi-band light curves to derive accurate mean magnitudes.
AI.result: Derived effective temperatures peaking around 3150 K, mass-loss rates spanning 1e-11 to 1e-4 Msun/yr, and inner dust temperatures near 1000 K. Found correlation between variability amplitude and mass-loss rate. Environmental dependencies influenced by luminosity distributions and selection effects rather than purely intrinsic metallicity differences.
AI.conclusion: Provides statistically robust view of carbon stars across different metallicity environments. Selection effects limit detection of highly obscured and faint sources, but observed trends remain significant within sampled populations, offering insights into carbon star evolution and dust production.

title: The dependence of triggering mechanisms on radio AGN sub-types: the role of galaxy mergers
comment: Accepted for publication in MNRAS. 23 pages, 17 figures
summary: Powerful, radio-loud active galactic nuclei (AGN) are associated with one of the most important forms of AGN feedback, and understanding how they are triggered is key to properly incorporating them into models of galaxy evolution. Here, we present the results of a deep Isaac Newton Telescope/Wide Field Camera imaging survey which, when combined with Gemini/Gemini Multi-Object Spectrograph South images, gives a 98 per cent complete sample of 112 3CR radio galaxies with redshifts $z$ < 0.3, alongside a stellar mass matched control sample. Our results provide strong evidence for significant differences ($\sim$3$σ$) between the triggering mechanisms of the different sub-types of powerful radio AGN. The high-excitation radio galaxies (HERGs) show a high rate of morphological disturbance (62$^{+6}_{-7}$ per cent) -- an excess of $\sim$4$σ$ compared with the control sample -- consistent with them being predominantly triggered in galaxy mergers and interactions. In contrast, the low-excitation radio galaxies (LERGs) show a much lower rate of morphological disturbance (36$^{+7}_{-6}$ per cent), consistent with the control sample, and suggesting a different dominant triggering mechanism, such as the accretion of gas from the hot X-ray haloes of the host galaxies or galaxy clusters. We also demonstrate that, when considering the radio morphology, the FRII HERG sources preferentially reside in disturbed morphologies, a difference of $\sim$3$σ$ to the FRII LERG objects. This suggests that the FRII LERG sources do not solely represent a `switched-off' phase in the HERG lifecycle of the same parent galaxy population as the FRII HERGs.

AI.tldr: Radio galaxy triggering mechanisms differ between high-excitation (HERG) and low-excitation (LERGs) types, with HERGs predominantly triggered by galaxy mergers/interactions while LERGs likely accrete from hot gas halos.
AI.motivation: Understanding the triggering mechanisms of powerful radio-loud AGN is crucial for properly incorporating AGN feedback into galaxy evolution models.
AI.method: Deep imaging survey using Isaac Newton Telescope/Wide Field Camera combined with Gemini/Gemini Multi-Object Spectrograph South images, providing a 98% complete sample of 112 3CR radio galaxies with z < 0.3 alongside a stellar mass matched control sample.
AI.result: HERGs show high morphological disturbance rate (62%) - 4σ excess compared to control - indicating merger/interaction triggering. LERGs show lower disturbance rate (36%), consistent with control, suggesting different triggering via hot gas halo accretion. FRII HERGs preferentially reside in disturbed morphologies compared to FRII LERGs (3σ difference).
AI.conclusion: Different sub-types of powerful radio AGN have distinct triggering mechanisms: HERGs primarily triggered by galaxy mergers/interactions, while LERGs likely triggered by accretion from hot X-ray haloes. FRII LERGs do not simply represent a 'switched-off' phase of FRII HERGs.

title: Inference of horizontal velocity fields from the induction equation in the solar atmosphere. I. Analytical and numerical solutions in 2D
comment: Accepted for publication at A&A: 17/02/2026
summary: Spectroscopic and spectropolarimetric observations, which rely on the Doppler effect, only provide access to the line-of-sight component of the solar plasma velocity (vz). However, many dynamic processes in the solar atmosphere involve strong horizontal motions (in the plane perpendicular to the line-of-sight: vx, vy). Existing methods for estimating horizontal velocities are generally insensitive to variations in height (the z-coordinate), providing them only on a single plane perpendicular to the line-of-sight: vx(x,y), vy(x,y). Motivated by the fact that modern analysis techniques allow us to retrieve the height dependence of vz and B, our goal is to infer also this height dependence for the horizontal velocity field in the solar atmosphere. As a first step, we present, and test a method for the two-dimensional case on the (y,z) plane so as to show that the z dependence can be successfully retrieved. The components of the two-dimensional magnetic induction equation are discretized via finite differences, leading to an overdetermined system whose solution provides vy. The method assumes that B, its time variation, as well as vz are known. This is currently possible through modern Stokes inversion techniques applied to spatially and temporally resolved spectropolarimetric observations. Using analytically prescribed values and two-dimensional magneto-hydrodynamic simulations of the solar surface, we demonstrate that, in these idealized cases, the horizontal velocity component in a two-dimensional domain, can be successfully recovered with a mean error of about 1 %. The proposed method successfully retrieves the horizontal velocity field in the (y,z) plane, thereby establishing the foundation for future extensions to three-dimensional reconstructions of the horizontal velocity field.

AI.tldr: A method to retrieve height-dependent horizontal velocity fields in solar atmosphere using magnetic induction equation, validated with 1% mean error in 2D cases.
AI.motivation: Spectroscopic observations only provide line-of-sight velocity components (vz), while solar dynamics involve strong horizontal motions (vx, vy). Existing methods lack height dependence, providing velocities only on single planes. Modern techniques can retrieve height dependence for vz and magnetic fields, so the goal is to extend this capability to horizontal velocity fields.
AI.method: Discretize components of the two-dimensional magnetic induction equation via finite differences, creating an overdetermined system whose solution provides vy. Assumes B, its time variation, and vz are known (obtainable through modern Stokes inversion techniques). Tested using analytically prescribed values and 2D MHD simulations of solar surface.
AI.result: In idealized cases, the horizontal velocity component in a 2D domain can be successfully recovered with mean error of about 1%. The method successfully retrieves horizontal velocity field in the (y,z) plane.
AI.conclusion: The proposed method establishes foundation for future extensions to 3D reconstructions of horizontal velocity field in solar atmosphere, addressing current limitations in solar velocity field measurements.

title: Magnetohydrodynamic Precipitation
comment: A tutorial submitted to PASP: 27 pages, 10 figures
summary: Circumgalactic gas around massive galaxies generally has a volume-filling component -- an atmosphere -- with a temperature determined by the potential-well depth of the galaxy's halo. If the atmosphere is near hydrostatic equilibrium and is stable to convection, then it can remain nearly homogeneous, as long as it is not too dense. But if its density is great enough, it becomes prone to producing a rain of cold clouds that fall toward the galaxy's center and accrete onto its central black hole. Here we explain how relatively weak magnetic fields enhance a galactic atmosphere's tendency to produce cold clouds and how the cold gas becomes organized into vertically elongated, highly magnetized filaments descending at sub-Keplerian speeds. It is intended to complement recent numerical simulations of the process and to serve as a guide to interpreting both simulations and observations of the filamentary gas in hot galactic atmospheres.

AI.tldr: Magnetic fields enhance cold cloud formation in hot galactic atmospheres, organizing cold gas into magnetized filaments that descend sub-Keplerianly toward galactic centers.
AI.motivation: To explain how weak magnetic fields enhance the tendency of hot galactic atmospheres to produce cold clouds and organize them into magnetized filaments, complementing recent simulations and guiding interpretation of observations.
AI.method: Theoretical explanation of how magnetic fields affect galactic atmosphere stability and cloud formation, focusing on hydrostatic equilibrium, convective stability, and magnetic field effects on cold gas organization.
AI.result: Magnetic fields promote cold cloud formation in dense galactic atmospheres, organizing the cold gas into vertically elongated, highly magnetized filaments that descend at sub-Keplerian speeds toward galactic centers.
AI.conclusion: Weak magnetic fields significantly enhance cold cloud production in galactic atmospheres and organize the resulting cold gas into magnetized filaments, providing theoretical framework for interpreting simulations and observations of filamentary gas in hot galactic atmospheres.

title: Morphological variations of solar granules in the presence of magnetic fields
summary: Solar granulation consists of dynamic convective plasma cells that rise from the solar interior to the surface. The interaction between these plasma cells and the Sun's magnetic field provides valuable insights into plasma dynamics near the solar surface and how they evolve in the presence of magnetic fields. This study analyses the morphological characteristics of solar convective cells, investigating the relationship between magnetic field properties and granule dynamics - specifically how granule area, shape, and brightness vary under different magnetic field conditions. Observations of the active region NOAA 11768 were taken with the Swedish 1-m Solar Telescope (SST). A segmentation algorithm was applied to continuum intensity images to identify individual granules and determine their sizes, shapes, and mean brightness. The magnetic field vector and line-of-sight velocity were derived from CRISP spectropolarimetric data to investigate their role in shaping granule properties. We find that granular area decreases systematically with increasing magnetic field strength, with the largest granules occurring in non-magnetic regions and a mean granule area of approximately 1.58 arcsec$^2$ (effective diameter of 1.42 arcseconds). Both mean continuum intensity and granule size decrease with stronger fields, confirming the suppression of convective energy transport in magnetised regions. No correlation was found between mean granule brightness and mean up-flow velocity. Highly elongated granules appear in both magnetic and non-magnetic regions, while near-circular granules are exclusive to non-magnetic areas. An alignment between granule major axes and magnetic field azimuth is observed where the horizontal field component is strong, confirming that granules are highly sensitive to magnetic fields, which inhibit the lateral expansion of convective cells.

AI.tldr: Solar granule size and brightness decrease with increasing magnetic field strength, confirming magnetic suppression of convection; granule elongation aligns with horizontal magnetic field direction.
AI.motivation: To understand how solar magnetic fields influence granule dynamics (area, shape, brightness) and provide insights into plasma dynamics near the solar surface in magnetized environments.
AI.method: Used Swedish 1-m Solar Telescope observations of active region NOAA 11768; applied segmentation algorithm to continuum intensity images to identify granules; derived magnetic field vector and line-of-sight velocity from CRISP spectropolarimetric data; analyzed correlations between magnetic field properties and granule characteristics.
AI.result: Granular area decreases systematically with increasing magnetic field strength (largest granules in non-magnetic regions, mean area ~1.58 arcsec²); mean continuum intensity and granule size both decrease with stronger fields; no correlation between brightness and up-flow velocity; elongated granules appear in both magnetic/non-magnetic regions, while near-circular granules only in non-magnetic areas; granule major axes align with magnetic field azimuth where horizontal field is strong.
AI.conclusion: Magnetic fields suppress convective energy transport by inhibiting lateral expansion of granules; granules are highly sensitive to magnetic fields, with their morphology directly influenced by field strength and orientation, particularly horizontal components.

title: Spectroscopic analysis and RHD modeling of the first Ca II H and H-epsilon flare spectra from DKIST/ViSP
comment: 34 pages, 8 figures; accepted for publication in Solar Physics
summary: We analyze decay phase observations of the GOES class C6.7 flare SOL2022-08-19T20:31 by the Visible Spectropolarimeter (ViSP) on the National Science Foundation's Daniel K. Inouye Solar Telescope (DKIST). The data include the first flare-time DKIST observations of the chromospheric Ca II H 396.8 nm and H-epsilon 397.0 nm spectral lines. These diagnostics have rarely been studied together during the modern era of high-resolution solar flare observations, and never at the spectral and spatial resolution of the DKIST. We directly compare DKIST spectra to state-of-the-art RADYN+RH simulations, including one heated by a nonthermal electron beam and one by in-situ thermal conduction. While certain salient properties of the spectra such as the width of H-epsilon are reproduced, the models severely underestimate the width of Ca II H in the red wing and fail to reproduce the exact relative intensity of Ca II H to H-epsilon. The models exhibit a range of condensation electron densities spanning over an order of magnitude. Unlike the modeled lower-order Balmer-series lines, we find that the width of H-epsilon is not solely related to the condensation properties; the widths and intensities are also sensitive to the deeper flare layers. We outline possible avenues towards improvement of flare models, such as a comprehensive evaluation of flare heating mechanisms in the context of both impulsive and decay phase high-resolution data.

AI.tldr: First DKIST flare observations of Ca II H and H-epsilon lines reveal discrepancies with RADYN+RH simulations, showing models underestimate Ca II H width and fail to reproduce line intensity ratios, suggesting need for improved flare heating mechanisms.
AI.motivation: To analyze first DKIST flare-time observations of chromospheric Ca II H and H-epsilon spectral lines at unprecedented resolution, comparing them with state-of-the-art flare simulations to test model accuracy and identify limitations.
AI.method: Used DKIST's Visible Spectropolarimeter (ViSP) to observe decay phase of GOES C6.7 flare SOL2022-08-19T20:31, capturing Ca II H 396.8 nm and H-epsilon 397.0 nm lines. Directly compared observations with RADYN+RH simulations including nonthermal electron beam heating and in-situ thermal conduction models.
AI.result: Models reproduced some properties like H-epsilon width but severely underestimated Ca II H red wing width and failed to reproduce exact relative intensity of Ca II H to H-epsilon. Models showed condensation electron densities spanning over an order of magnitude. Unlike lower-order Balmer lines, H-epsilon width was not solely related to condensation properties but also sensitive to deeper flare layers.
AI.conclusion: Current flare models have significant limitations in reproducing high-resolution spectral observations. Need comprehensive evaluation of flare heating mechanisms using both impulsive and decay phase data to improve model accuracy and understanding of flare physics.

title: Mechanisms Affecting Galaxies Nearby and Environmental Trends (MAGNET)
comment: Revised version after referee's comments. 29 pages plus Appendix
summary: [ABRIDGED] Galaxy evolution is shaped by internal and external mechanisms that regulate the baryon cycle and star formation activity. We present a theoretical framework based on the GAlaxy Evolution and Assembly (GAEA) semi-analytic model. We extracted portions of simulated volumes that include isolated galaxies, pairs, group, and filament members at z ~ 0, specifically avoiding massive clusters. Galaxies were classified using both intrinsic (halo-based) and observational (2D projected) parameterizations, reconstructing their environmental histories from z = 2 and identifying mergers, tidal interactions, ram pressure stripping (RPS), and starvation. 2D information decreases isolated and group fractions while doubles pairs. More than half of galaxies remain unaffected by the investigated processes since z = 2. Among affected galaxies, mergers dominate at high stellar masses (40-60% at log(M*/Msun) > 10.5). Tidal interactions are less frequent, and their incidence increases with stellar mass. RPS dominates in groups and filaments at intermediate masses (~50%), while starvation ranges from 20 to 30%. The incidence of the different mechanisms depends strongly on both mass and environment, though their imprints on global properties are often subtle. Distinct evolutionary pathways emerge: log(M*/Msun) < 9.5, galaxies in groups and filaments have a faster mass growth than galaxies in the other environments, especially those undergoing starvation, mergers and, to less extent, RPS. Differences are reduced moving to higher masses, where no clear dependence on physical mechanism emerge, even though at these masses a clear star formation suppression is evident in mergers and starved galaxies. This theoretical investigation provides essential context for the recently started multi-wavelength program Mechanisms Affecting Galaxies Nearby and Environmental Trends (MAGNET), which we introduce here.

AI.tldr: Theoretical study using GAEA semi-analytic model to quantify environmental effects (mergers, tidal interactions, ram pressure stripping, starvation) on galaxy evolution across different environments, providing context for the MAGNET observational program.
AI.motivation: To understand how internal and external mechanisms shape galaxy evolution by quantifying the relative importance of different environmental processes (mergers, tidal interactions, ram pressure stripping, starvation) across various environments and mass ranges.
AI.method: Used GAEA semi-analytic model to extract simulated volumes containing isolated galaxies, pairs, group, and filament members at z~0, avoiding massive clusters. Classified galaxies using both intrinsic (halo-based) and observational (2D projected) parameterizations, reconstructing environmental histories from z=2 to identify specific mechanisms.
AI.result: More than half of galaxies remain unaffected since z=2. Among affected galaxies: mergers dominate at high stellar masses (40-60% at log(M*/Msun)>10.5); tidal interactions increase with stellar mass; RPS dominates in groups/filaments at intermediate masses (~50%); starvation ranges 20-30%. Environmental imprints on global properties are often subtle but distinct evolutionary pathways emerge: low-mass galaxies in groups/filaments grow faster, especially those undergoing starvation, mergers, and RPS. At high masses, mergers and starved galaxies show clear star formation suppression.
AI.conclusion: The incidence of different environmental mechanisms depends strongly on both mass and environment, with distinct evolutionary pathways emerging across mass ranges. This theoretical framework provides essential context for the MAGNET observational program to study environmental effects on nearby galaxies.

title: Hot subdwarf stars from the Hamburg Quasar Survey
comment: A&A accepted, 14 pages, 8 page appendix, 12 figures
summary: Hot subluminous stars (sdO/B) are evolved low mass stars originating from red giants that lost their envelope almost entirely. The multitude of observed phenomena imply that several pathways may form hot subdwarfs, most involving close binary channels. The Hamburg Quasar Survey (HQS) led to the discovery of many faint blue stars including hot subdwarf. Many of the HQS-sdB stars have been studied in detail, but analyses of the helium-rich sdOB and sdO stars are lacking. The recent development of hybrid LTE/non-LTE model spectra 2nd generation Bamberg model grids enables us to improve the spectroscopic analyses of the sdB stars as well as of the previously unstudied sdO stars allowing precise atmospheric parameters to be derived, while consistently accounting for parameter correlations and systematic uncertainties. ... We use spectral energy distributions to identify composite-colour sdB binaries and present the result of detailed spectroscopic analyses of 122 non-composite subdwarfs from the HQS to identify potential evolutionary pathways. ...Their derived mass distribution and median mass of 0.45 Msun is consistent with the canonical EHB mass. ... The helium-rich sdOB and sdO stars, are found near the helium main-sequence (He-MS). The derived mass distribution of the extremely He-rich subdwarfs is broader (0.48 to 1.05 Msun) and peaks at a median of 0.70 Msun, significantly larger than those of the hydrogen-rich stars. Intermediate He-rich subdwarfs are also He-MS stars, but of lower mass (0.55 Msun) than the extremely He-rich. This strongly supports the merger scenario for the origin of He-rich sdO stars, in which two helium white dwarfs merge following orbital decay driven by gravitational-wave emission, producing a He-rich sdO or sdOB star. From comparison to the results of similar studies we speculate that older populations produce more massive He-WD mergers.(abbreviated)

AI.tldr: Analysis of 122 non-composite hot subdwarfs from HQS reveals two distinct populations: hydrogen-rich sdBs with median mass ~0.45 M☉ consistent with canonical EHB evolution, and helium-rich sdOB/sdOs with higher median mass ~0.70 M☉ supporting binary white dwarf merger origin.
AI.motivation: Previous studies of HQS hot subdwarfs focused mainly on sdB stars, leaving helium-rich sdOB and sdO stars poorly analyzed. The development of improved hybrid LTE/non-LTE model spectra enables precise atmospheric parameter determination and systematic study of these previously unanalyzed populations to identify evolutionary pathways.
AI.method: Used spectral energy distributions to identify composite-color sdB binaries, then performed detailed spectroscopic analyses of 122 non-composite subdwarfs from HQS using 2nd generation Bamberg model grids (hybrid LTE/non-LTE model spectra) to derive precise atmospheric parameters while accounting for correlations and systematic uncertainties.
AI.result: Hydrogen-rich sdB stars show mass distribution peaking at median 0.45 M☉ consistent with canonical EHB mass. Helium-rich sdOB/sdO stars cluster near helium main-sequence with broader mass distribution (0.48-1.05 M☉) and higher median mass of 0.70 M☉. Intermediate He-rich stars have lower mass (~0.55 M☉) than extremely He-rich stars.
AI.conclusion: The distinct mass distributions strongly support different formation channels: hydrogen-rich sdBs follow canonical EHB evolution, while helium-rich sdO/sdOB stars originate from binary white dwarf mergers where two helium white dwarfs merge following gravitational-wave orbital decay. Older stellar populations may produce more massive He-WD mergers.

title: Bridging Scales in Black Hole Accretion and Feedback: Subgrid Prescription from First Principles
comment: 10 pages, 4 figures
summary: Understanding how supermassive black holes (BHs) couple to their host galaxies across a vast spatial and temporal dynamic range remains a central challenge in galaxy evolution. Using the multizone framework -- designed to capture bidirectional inflow--outflow from the event horizon to the Bondi scale -- we present a suite of long-duration GRMHD simulations spanning BH spins $|a_\ast|=0$--0.9 and Bondi radii $R_B/r_g=4\times10^2$--$2\times10^6$. From these simulations we derive spin-dependent subgrid prescriptions from first principles, applicable to hot accretion flows with low-Eddington ratios ($f_{\rm Edd}\lesssim10^{-3}$), for adoption in cosmological simulations and semi-analytic models. We provide compact analytic fits for the time-averaged accretion rate $\dot M(R_B,a_\ast)$ and feedback power $\dot E_{\rm fb}(R_B,a_\ast)$ with respect to the Bondi rate $\dot{M}_B$, which are largely insensitive to the initial gas configuration and magnetic field strength. To capture intrinsic time-variability, we also quantify the full distributions of $\dot M$ and feedback efficiency $η$, both well described by lognormal statistics, with widths that increase toward larger $R_B$. We further measure self-consistent spin evolution in the hot accretion mode, finding that the spin-up parameter varies as $s(a_\ast)\simeq -3.7\,a_\ast$, which implies a very long spindown timescale $t_s\simeq 12(10^{-3}/f_{\rm Edd})\,{\rm Gyr}$. Thus, BH spins are effectively frozen during phases of quiescent accretion. Compared to conventional small-domain GRMHD calculations, our simulations, which reach dynamical equilibrium across horizon-to-galaxy scales, yield systematically different long-term accretion, feedback, and spin properties, cautioning against direct extrapolation from small-scale GRMHD simulations when constructing galactic-scale subgrid models.

AI.tldr: The paper presents a suite of long-duration GRMHD simulations to derive first-principles subgrid prescriptions for supermassive black hole accretion and feedback in low-Eddington hot accretion flows, revealing that BH spins remain effectively frozen during quiescent accretion phases.
AI.motivation: To understand how supermassive black holes couple to their host galaxies across vast spatial and temporal scales, and to develop first-principles subgrid prescriptions for cosmological simulations and semi-analytic models that capture bidirectional inflow-outflow from event horizon to Bondi scale.
AI.method: Used multizone framework with long-duration GRMHD simulations spanning BH spins |a*|=0-0.9 and Bondi radii RB/rg=4×10²-2×10⁶, analyzing hot accretion flows with low-Eddington ratios (f_Edd≲10⁻³) to derive time-averaged accretion rates, feedback power, and spin evolution.
AI.result: Derived compact analytic fits for accretion rate and feedback power relative to Bondi rate; quantified lognormal distributions of accretion rate and feedback efficiency; found spin-up parameter s(a*)≃-3.7a* with long spindown timescale ts≃12(10⁻³/f_Edd) Gyr, indicating effectively frozen BH spins during quiescent accretion.
AI.conclusion: BH spins remain effectively frozen during phases of quiescent accretion, and simulations reaching dynamical equilibrium across horizon-to-galaxy scales yield systematically different long-term accretion, feedback, and spin properties compared to conventional small-domain GRMHD calculations, cautioning against direct extrapolation when constructing galactic-scale subgrid models.

title: The Montreal Open Clusters and Associations (MOCA) Database: A Census of Nearby Associations, Open Clusters, and Young Substellar Objects within 500 pc of the Sun
comment: Accepted for publication in ApJS, 26 figures, 9 tables. See source material for complete tables
summary: We present the Montreal Open Clusters and Associations database (MOCAdb), a public MySQL database with a Python interface. MOCAdb provides a census of memberships for 10259 associations and open clusters within 500 pc of the Sun, with a comprehensive compilation of literature measurements such as spectral types, kinematics, rotation periods, activity indices, spectral indices, and photometry. All known substellar objects are cataloged in MOCAdb, along with 2943 public spectra, to enable the characterization of substellar association members. MOCAdb also features periodically updated calculations such as Galactic UVW space velocities. We use this compilation to construct mappings between independent association definitions, and to update the BANYAN $Σ$ membership classification tool, which now includes 8125 associations. The BANYAN $Σ$ model construction is improved to account for heterogeneous and correlated errors and to capture complex association shapes using Gaussian mixture models. Combined with Gaia DR3, this enabled us to identify 11535 yet unrecognized candidate members of young associations within 500 pc, mostly M dwarfs. Our results corroborate a recent observation that systematics up to $\approx$4 km/s remain in Gaia DR3 radial velocities for A-type stars. We present an updated census of age-calibrated exoplanets and substellar objects: 134 age-calibrated exoplanet systems (plus 121 TESS exoplanet candidates), 99 of which did not appear to have known memberships so far, and 455 substellar (L0 or later) candidate members of young associations, 196 of which appear newly recognized. We bring the total of candidate isolated planetary-mass objects to 101, 53 of which are newly recognized candidate members.

AI.tldr: MOCAdb is a public database with Python interface providing comprehensive membership census for 10,259 associations/clusters within 500 pc, featuring updated BANYAN Σ classification tool that identified 11,535 new candidate members and updated census of age-calibrated exoplanets/substellar objects.
AI.motivation: To create a comprehensive, publicly accessible database for young stellar associations and open clusters within 500 pc that integrates heterogeneous literature measurements, enables characterization of substellar members, and improves membership classification tools to identify previously unrecognized members.
AI.method: Developed MOCAdb as a MySQL database with Python interface, compiling literature measurements (spectral types, kinematics, rotation periods, activity indices, spectral indices, photometry). Updated BANYAN Σ classification tool using Gaussian mixture models to handle heterogeneous/correlated errors and complex association shapes. Combined with Gaia DR3 data to identify new candidate members.
AI.result: Identified 11,535 previously unrecognized candidate members of young associations within 500 pc (mostly M dwarfs). Updated census includes 134 age-calibrated exoplanet systems (+121 TESS candidates), 455 substellar candidate members (196 newly recognized), and 101 candidate isolated planetary-mass objects (53 newly recognized). Confirmed systematic errors (~4 km/s) in Gaia DR3 radial velocities for A-type stars.
AI.conclusion: MOCAdb provides a comprehensive resource for studying young associations and open clusters, with improved membership classification enabling discovery of thousands of new candidate members. The database facilitates characterization of substellar objects and age-calibrated exoplanets, advancing our understanding of stellar and planetary system formation and evolution.

title: Aligned and misaligned metallicity gradients in young stars and star-forming regions in the EAGLE discs
comment: 10 pages, 7 figures, accepted for publication in A&A
summary: Disc galaxies exhibit radial metallicity gradients in both their stellar and gaseous components. The star-forming gas (SFG) in HII regions and young stars (YSs) trace the recent evolutionary history of the galaxy. We aim to assess the extent to which the joint analysis of metallicity gradient alignment in YSs and SFG can constrain the recent evolutionary history of galaxies. Using the high-resolution run of the EAGLE project, we derived radial, azimuthally averaged oxygen abundance profiles for YSs (age < 2 Gyr) and SFG and measured their gradients as the slopes of linear fits to these profiles. We classified galaxies into four groups based on the signs (N for negative and P for positive) of the slopes: NN, NP, PP, and PN (the first letter is for YSs and the second for SFG). We found that galaxies with NN, NP, PP, and PN combinations of metallicity profiles reflect different evolutionary paths over the past ~ 2 Gyr. NN galaxies exhibit sustained inside-out growth accompanied by high star formation efficiency, whereas NP and PP systems show evidence of recent or ongoing feedback-driven disruption, with PP galaxies likely being predominantly shaped by supernova feedback. PN galaxies, by contrast, show evidence of past violent events followed by gradient recovery, highlighting the interplay between inflows, feedback, and gas cooling in shaping metallicity distributions. The degree of alignment between the stellar and gas metallicity gradients provides a way to time the occurrence of significant events in the evolutionary history of galaxies, which contribute through a combination of gas inflows, star formation triggering, and metal mixing. They could also serve as probes of sub-grid physics when observations provide suitable comparison datasets. [Abridged]

AI.tldr: Analysis of radial metallicity gradients in disc galaxies using EAGLE simulations shows that alignment patterns between young stars and star-forming gas gradients reveal different evolutionary histories over ~2 Gyr.
AI.motivation: To assess how joint analysis of metallicity gradient alignment in young stars and star-forming gas can constrain recent evolutionary history of galaxies, using these gradients as tracers of recent galactic evolution.
AI.method: Used high-resolution EAGLE simulations to derive radial oxygen abundance profiles for young stars (age < 2 Gyr) and star-forming gas, measured gradients via linear fits, and classified galaxies into four groups based on slope signs (NN, NP, PP, PN).
AI.result: Different gradient combinations reflect distinct evolutionary paths: NN galaxies show sustained inside-out growth with high star formation efficiency; NP and PP systems indicate recent/ongoing feedback-driven disruption; PN galaxies reveal past violent events followed by gradient recovery.
AI.conclusion: Alignment between stellar and gas metallicity gradients provides timing information for significant evolutionary events and serves as probe of sub-grid physics when compared with observational data.

title: Impact of rotation on the amplitude of acoustic modes in solar-like stars: Insights from hydrodynamical simulations
comment: Submitted to MNRAS
summary: In solar-like stars, acoustic modes provide the main way of probing their internal structure and dynamics. Although these modes are expected to be ubiquitous in stars with convective envelopes, Kepler observations reveal that a significant fraction of solar-like stars show no detectable acoustic modes, particularly among rapidly rotating and magnetically active stars. Recent theoretical work by Bessila et al. (2025) has proposed that rotation tends to inhibit convective motions, thereby reducing the power available for stochastic mode excitation. Here, we test this prediction using fully compressible hydrodynamical simulations of a solar-like star. We perform a series of 2.5D simulations, which consider longitudinal symmetry, using the MUSIC code spanning rotation rates from 0 to 8 $Ω_{\odot}$. We find a clear and systematic decline of acoustic mode amplitudes with increasing rotation rate. In the most rapidly rotating models, mode damping rates are also enhanced. The combined reduction in excitation and increase in damping with increasing rotation rate provide a physical explanation for the observed decrease in mode detectability in rapidly rotating solar-like stars. Our results demonstrate that rotation can significantly modify oscillation properties and must be accounted for when interpreting asteroseismic observations.

AI.tldr: Rotation reduces acoustic mode amplitudes and increases damping rates in solar-like stars, explaining why rapidly rotating stars show fewer detectable oscillations in Kepler observations.
AI.motivation: To test the theoretical prediction by Bessila et al. (2025) that rotation inhibits convective motions and reduces power for stochastic mode excitation, explaining why many rapidly rotating solar-like stars show no detectable acoustic modes in Kepler observations.
AI.method: Performed 2.5D simulations with longitudinal symmetry using the MUSIC code, spanning rotation rates from 0 to 8 solar rotation rates (Ω⊙), employing fully compressible hydrodynamical simulations of a solar-like star.
AI.result: Found clear systematic decline of acoustic mode amplitudes with increasing rotation rate, with enhanced damping rates in most rapidly rotating models, demonstrating combined reduction in excitation and increase in damping with rotation.
AI.conclusion: Rotation significantly modifies oscillation properties by reducing excitation and increasing damping, providing physical explanation for decreased mode detectability in rapidly rotating solar-like stars, necessitating consideration of rotation in asteroseismic interpretation.

title: WISDOM Project - XXVII. Giant molecular clouds of the lenticular galaxy NGC 1387: similarities with spiral galaxy clouds
comment: 26 pages, 17 figures, accepted by MNRAS
summary: Molecular gas is crucial to understanding star formation and galaxy evolution, but the giant molecular clouds (GMCs) of early-type galaxies (ETGs) have rarely been studied. Here, we present analyses of the spatially resolved GMCs of the lenticular galaxy NGC 1387, exploiting high spatial resolution (0.15" or 14 pc) 12CO(2-1) line observations from the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array. We identify 1285 individual GMCs and measure the fundamental properties (radius, velocity dispersion, and molecular gas mass) of each with a modified version of the CPROPStoo package. Unusually for an ETG, the GMCs of NGC 1387 follow scaling relations very similar to those of the Milky Way disc and Local Group galaxy clouds, and most are virialised. GMCs with large masses and radii and/or small galactocentric distances have their angular momenta aligned with the large-scale galactic rotation, while other GMCs do not. These results show that ETGs have more diversified GMC properties than previously thought. We discuss potential reasons for such diversity, and viewing-angle dependency is a plausible candidate.

AI.tldr: Analysis of giant molecular clouds (GMCs) in lenticular galaxy NGC 1387 reveals they follow Milky Way-like scaling relations, are mostly virialized, and show diverse angular momentum alignment patterns, challenging previous assumptions about ETG molecular clouds.
AI.motivation: Giant molecular clouds (GMCs) in early-type galaxies (ETGs) are poorly studied despite their importance for understanding star formation and galaxy evolution. This research aims to characterize GMC properties in the lenticular galaxy NGC 1387 to address this knowledge gap.
AI.method: Used high spatial resolution (0.15" or 14 pc) ALMA 12CO(2-1) line observations to identify 1285 individual GMCs. Applied modified CPROPStoo package to measure fundamental properties (radius, velocity dispersion, molecular gas mass) of each cloud.
AI.result: NGC 1387 GMCs follow scaling relations similar to Milky Way disc and Local Group galaxies, with most being virialized. Large, massive GMCs near galactic center have angular momenta aligned with galactic rotation, while others do not, showing diverse properties.
AI.conclusion: ETGs have more diversified GMC properties than previously thought. Viewing-angle dependency is suggested as a plausible explanation for this diversity, challenging conventional understanding of molecular clouds in early-type galaxies.
